body:
Some more information:

Here is the full GDB log: https://gist.github.com/nickodell/6b8450006080c2d41091b7b84f034c72

I had SciPy commit https://github.com/scipy/scipy/commit/ab936e4839 checked out when I ran this.

The crash happens in Cython 3.2.0 but not Cython 3.1.6. I have not bisected it further within Cython than this.

For context, the import that is failing is on a line within `scipy/sparse/csgraph/_reordering.pyx`. It is attempting to run `from . import maximum_bipartite_matching`, where `.` should refer to `scipy.sparse.csgraph`.

_Originally posted by @nickodell in https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/7035#issuecomment-3494121320_

comment_data.body:
Bisect says the first commit where this import doesn't work is a67f0401995318ba99f98ddfd29220f60dbe3d32.

<details>

Bisect log

```
git bisect start
# bad: [e6533f887fbde09d265ea85765d2e2fa235b38e5] Prepare release of 3.2.0.
git bisect bad e6533f887fbde09d265ea85765d2e2fa235b38e5
# good: [b40c676a7396e3b8ca25974bd5ca4b5cef7f9908] Prepare release of 3.1.6.
git bisect good b40c676a7396e3b8ca25974bd5ca4b5cef7f9908
# good: [8906d22a6f521bf69532b02e6320b214589dad2a] Extract common code from the fused functions dispatch into utility functions (GH-7097)
git bisect good 8906d22a6f521bf69532b02e6320b214589dad2a
# good: [fbf05102c084e3528e5f69c71ce2952f4436438e] Avoid a C compiler warning about an unused function argument introduced in https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/7115
git bisect good fbf05102c084e3528e5f69c71ce2952f4436438e
# good: [6770b56ef59616568005a7c78e29f494cc1ca5ec] Clarify the explanatory isolation comment @ `coverage_cmd_src_pkg_layout` test (GH-7203)
git bisect good 6770b56ef59616568005a7c78e29f494cc1ca5ec
# bad: [874572e02e4a639d94aa9c38a6bdaa35824251d9] Silence a C coercion warning in a test.
git bisect bad 874572e02e4a639d94aa9c38a6bdaa35824251d9
# good: [02d05df63381862f312e5973787932fb106c664f] Do not trivially immortalise string constants since not all strings are valid immortal strings.
git bisect good 02d05df63381862f312e5973787932fb106c664f
# good: [08b15fc4f44bdb3e62985bc141f99a6f1d5ec279] Merge branch '3.1.x'
git bisect good 08b15fc4f44bdb3e62985bc141f99a6f1d5ec279
# bad: [440b19a36e3c145f6ba6a7b84199c246c1902184] Disable parallelism in `cythonize` command/function on `spawn` (GH-7183)
git bisect bad 440b19a36e3c145f6ba6a7b84199c246c1902184
# bad: [e89d614811ef1483d9aaefac0ff7492b53d108c8] Update changelog.
git bisect bad e89d614811ef1483d9aaefac0ff7492b53d108c8
# bad: [0437037c81ac3da417409cc6a5a07103d1b6c737] CI: Add PyDebug test job (GH-7243)
git bisect bad 0437037c81ac3da417409cc6a5a07103d1b6c737
# bad: [a67f0401995318ba99f98ddfd29220f60dbe3d32] Move more C code into the shared utility module (GH-7238)
git bisect bad a67f0401995318ba99f98ddfd29220f60dbe3d32
# first bad commit: [a67f0401995318ba99f98ddfd29220f60dbe3d32] Move more C code into the shared utility module (GH-7238)
```

</details>

I tried using master, but reverting that specific commit. This also works.

Only some of the changes in that patch relate to imports, so I also tried the following patch, which only reverts part of a67f0401995318ba99f98ddfd29220f60dbe3d32. This also works.

```diff
diff --git a/Cython/Utility/ImportExport.c b/Cython/Utility/ImportExport.c
index 283c64d71..270eae42d 100644
--- a/Cython/Utility/ImportExport.c
+++ b/Cython/Utility/ImportExport.c
@@ -1,4 +1,4 @@
-/////////////// Import.proto ///////////////
+/////////////// Import.export ///////////////
 
 static PyObject *__Pyx_Import(PyObject *name, PyObject *const *imported_names, Py_ssize_t len_imported_names, PyObject *qualname, int level); /*proto*/
 
```

I have a theory about why this error happens.

If I understand correctly, the commit is moving code from being duplicated into every generated C file to being one shared copy.

When it calls the shared copy, it calls `PyImport_ImportModuleLevelObject`. One of the arguments to this function is the globals of the module attempting import. [Docs](https://docs.python.org/3/c-api/import.html#c.PyImport_ImportModuleLevelObject)

```
            /* try package relative import first */
            module = PyImport_ImportModuleLevelObject(
                name, NAMED_CGLOBAL(moddict_cname), empty_dict, from_list, 1);
```

That appears to use the globals of the shared module. According to a comment in CPython, "The 'globals' argument is used to infer where the import is occurring to handle relative imports." [Source](https://github.com/python/cpython/blob/3.14/Lib/importlib/_bootstrap.py#L1465).

My best guess is that the three conditions necessary to trigger the bug are:

1. Using a shared Cython library.
2. Attempting a relative import.
3. The shared Cython library and module attempting a relative import are in different directories.

That's very useful. I think there's a fairly simple change that lets us keep it shared.

But there probably is a list of things that we're going to have to be careful of in shared utility code that aren't all completely obvious.

Nice analysis. I was afraid that `Import.proto` will cause issues but I double-checked that so I was confident with that. :-/ I will create a PR reverting that change. @nickodell could you validate whether the PR is fixing the issue in Scipy?

> I will create a PR reverting that change

Please don't! I've almost finished a better fix

The fix looks good. I tested it, and it fixes SciPy's issue. See linked PR for more details.

Also, since the previous PR was concerned with code size, I wanted to make a comparison of how many lines each approach takes.

I compared how many lines of code were added and removed by various solutions, when looking at the code generated for all of SciPy's Cython. (Numbers were found via `grep -R -l "/* Generated by Cython" build | xargs wc -l`)

Here is a table comparing how much generated code each version of Cython creates.

| Version                  | Generated Lines | Lines added VS 3.2.0 |
|--------------------------|-----------------|----------------------|
| 3.1.6                    |         1650951 |               118657 |
| 3.2.0                    |         1532294 |                    0 |
| njo-export-test |         1539324 |                 7030 |
| #7292      |         1532726 |                  432 |

The branch njo-export-test is a branch with [this diff](https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/7290#issuecomment-3499181865). The branch #7292 both fixes the test failure, and uses many fewer lines to accomplish it. Therefore I think it is the best option here.

As a side note, if I'm reading this right, Cython removed 100K lines of code off of our build between 3.1.6 and 3.2.0. That is some really incredible work that I am very appreciative of.

Lines possibly isn't the best metric (in that Limited API for example will add a large number of lines but they'll all be trivially selected or deselected by the preprocessor so shouldn't cost you anything). But hopefully the binary size is reduced too which is the real aim.

Nice digging! @nickodell for reference, the binary size of wheels (or a local build with `-Dbuildtype=release`) should be the most relevant metric to look at. It improved by 1.8 MB on average when adding the shared utility code with Cython 3.1.0 (xref https://github.com/scipy/scipy/pull/22796). It looks like 3.2.0 may have yielded some further gains.

I compared latest wheel build [1] using latest Cython 3.2 vs pypi [2] and for cp311 manylinux x86_64 is binary size **35.3 MB** (CI build) vs. **35.9 MB** (pypi) (I understand that the version of scipy is different and hence the size can be affected by other factors)

I checked scikit-learn too - **9.1 MB** [3]  (CI build using cython 3.2, cp311-manylinux_2_27_x86_64) vs. **9.7 MB** [4] (PyPi build cp311-manylinux2014_x86_64)

Hence, it seems roughtly ~**0.5 MB** space saved when migrated to cython 3.2 from cython 3.1.X.

[1] https://github.com/scipy/scipy/actions/runs/19163731257
[2] https://pypi.org/project/scipy/#files
[3] https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/actions/runs/19157595370
[4] https://pypi.org/project/scikit-learn/#files

> binary size

Is that the (compressed) wheel size or the size of the uncompressed, installed binary modules? If the first (i.e. basically the download size), then I think the latter would also be interesting.

It's the compressed size of the `.whl` file. And yes, the installed size is also interesting. A little harder to measure though since (a) it's not a single file, and (b) the default way devs build it locally contains debug info, so isn't representative for end user installs.

labels.description: Cython module for code sharing between multiple modules.
labels.name: sharedlib

title: Relative import is failing in the scipy project
